question: Question_07_(a)
statement:
The probability that a newly divided cell will divide again
\textbf{before} \emph{t} hours (where \emph{t} $\geq$ 0) is given by

\[F(t) = 1-e^{-t/12}\]

(a) If you start observing a cell immediately after a division, how
long, on average, would you have to wait to see the next division?
sols:
To get from the cumulative function to the probability density function,
you need to take the derivate, i.e.

\[p(t) = F'(t) = \frac1{12}e^{-t/12}.\]

Now we apply the definition of the expected value to the random variable
\emph{X} that denotes the waiting time:

\[\overline{X} = \int_0^\infty tp(t)\,dt.\]

This is an improper integral, so we treat it with caution. To solve it,
we apply integration by parts with \emph{u=t} and \emph{dv =
e\textsuperscript{-t/12}dt} and obtain

\begin{align*} \overline{X} &= \int_0^\infty tp(t)\,dt \\
&= \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} \left(\frac1{12} \int_0^T te^{-t/12}\,dt\right) \\
&= \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} \left(\left.\frac1{12} t(-12e^{-t/12})\right|_0^T + \frac1{12} \int_0^T 12e^{-t/12}\,dt\right) \\
&= \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} \left(-Te^{-T/12} + 0 - \left.12e^{-t/12}\right|_0^T\right) \\
&= \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} \left(-12e^{-T/12} + 12e^0\right) \\
&= 12;
\end{align*}

From class and the course notes you may remember that waiting time
typically has a probability density function and cumulative function of
the form

\[p(t) = ke^{-kt}, \quad \text{and} \quad F(t) = 1-e^{-kt},\]

respectively. In this case, the expected waiting time is given by
\emph{1/k}. Here \emph{k = 1/12} so that the expected value is
\emph{12}.
hints:
Recall that the average value of a continuous random variable \emph{X}
with values between \emph{a} and \emph{b} and probability density
function \emph{p(X=x) = p(x)} is defined as

\[\int_a^b xp(x)\,dx\]

How can you relate the given cumulative function \emph{F(t)} to the
probability density function \emph{p(t)}?

For a quick solution: The given cumulative function is the typical
cumulative function of a \emph{waiting time}. The expected waiting time
is already hidden in the exponential function.
